tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Valerie and Tatiana discuss the updates on the Falcon and Winter Soldier series, plus ask more Avengers: Endgame questions...
caption:
Valerie and Tatiana discuss the updates on the Falcon and Winter Soldier series, plus ask more Avengers: Endgame questions (0:40). Bryan Cogman as the showrunner for the Middle Earth prequel (10:40) then serves as its own prequel to our Game of Thrones discussion, which begins at 15:45 with an overview of the final episode and season before going into character breakdowns: Daenerys Targaryen (25:20), Jon Snow (31:05), Tyrion Lannister (36:25), Bran Stark (45:20), Sansa Stark (52:00) and Arya Stark (1:01:00). Then we dive into comparisons to A Song of Ice and Fire (1:05:20) and whether we will watch the spin-offs (1:16:40). Valerie talks Supernatural’s final season for some lighter content (1:21:10) and we end with other shows that didn’t stick the landing, like Battlestar Galactica and How I Met Your Mother (1:27:00).

You can let us know your thoughts in the comments below, or on our Podomatic page here.

Volatile, self-obsessed, doesn't play well with others, and very sexually frustrated.

Welcome to Frost Iron! A blog dedicated to all things Loki/Tony or Tony/Loki if you prefer. If you have any questions or want to submit anything just hit up our ask or submit box. Note: this is a blog for the characters and no RPS(F) will be posted.

Blog owner

summary: I just realized the Russos and M&M just don't know how to build things. How to build characters, how to build relationships....
body:
I just realized the Russos and M&M just don’t know how to build things. How to build characters, how to build relationships. They only know how to break them. And that’s where they fail. They’ve created relationships - Sharon/Steve, Wanda/Vision, just to take them away - just to break them later. They’ve proved unable to develop Pepperony, they didn’t even give us a Pepper/Tony/Morgan scene - they only knew how to break them. Break them the hardest way.

Bucky - they never did his character justice. They only ever used him as a plot device. Never developed him. They’ve never given us an actual Bucky/Steve reunion scene - stucky shipper or not, they were supposed to be best friends but their friendship was never developed. Never shown. Only mentioned. We were supposed to know it and that was enough for them. Out of 3 reunion scenes we could’ve had, we never had an actual one. They gave them a goodbye scene instead. Again, they knew how to break them. But not how to build them.

They’ve ruined Thor’s character development. He had such a huge character development in Ragnarok and they reduced him to a joke. Because they didn’t know how to build him - I mean I like the idea of showing that even the strongest people can hit the bottom but was it really necessary with Thor? I think they just didn’t know how to build him anymore, because he was already too strong for them.

They ruined Loki by erasing everything that made him powerful - his jotun heritage, his magic tricks, his manipulations. His character development (I know this is divisive but I personally liked his character development in Ragnarok).

They knew damn well how to break the Avengers in Civil War but they proved unable to build them back properly in Endgame.

I believe everything and everyone they didn’t know what to make of, they erased, killed, broke or ruined them.

Basically they knew damn well how to break our hearts. But they never knew how to fix the mess.

blog.name: originaljediinjeans
blog.title: One Wandering Jedi
blog.description:
Yes, it hurt when I fell from heaven, meaning when Order 66 happened and I had to leave my home galaxy.
IRL: I am a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day saints. I'm a cosplayer, a fangirl, an artist, and a dreamer. Top fandoms: Star Wars, Harry Potter, MCU/Avengers, Lord of the Rings. My favorite Disney princess is Mira Nova. I'm also madly in love with Bucky Barnes. In case you haven't figured it out by now, I'm autistic.

summary: “The scene of Natasha Romanoff (Black Widow, played by Scarlett Johansson) and Clint Barton (Hawkeye, played by Jeremy Renner)...
body:
“The scene of Natasha Romanoff (Black Widow, played by Scarlett Johansson) and Clint Barton (Hawkeye, played by Jeremy Renner) searching for the Soul Stone on Vormir led to one of the most dramatic moments in “Endgame.”…

But originally, the scene was very different.

“On script and what we first shot was an excellent scene,” Schmidt said. “Thanos and his soldiers show up on Vormir and a small battle ensues between them and Natasha and Clint. Natasha decides to run off the cliff. Clint tries to stop her while also fending off the attack.”

Schmidt said Black Widow’s original death scene was shown to test audiences and the reaction was positive, but after some time with the footage a new idea for the scene began to take form.

“It was reshot to make it more intimate between Clint and Natasha, which fully worked in the end version of the movie,” Schmidt said. “We just came up with a better idea, something that serviced Natasha a little bit more.” (source)


Me: WAIT WHAT? (I wrote a similar scene after seeing Endgame)

summary:
Do Hulk and Banner share a soul, or do they each have their own?
If Bruce had been on Vormir and jumped, would it just be all...
body:
Do Hulk and Banner share a soul, or do they each have their own?

If Bruce had been on Vormir and jumped, would it just be all Hulk all the time?

Or say he wasn’t Prof. Hulk, and the Hulk persona jumped and made the sacrifice, would Banner then be “cured” of the Hulk?

Cause that would be a good ending for the character.

Hulk goes out as a hero, and Banner gets the cure.

…or, they’d both have died lmao.

Is it two souls in one body? Does each personality have it’s own soul? Do they share a soul?

🤷‍♂️

blog.name: damngcoffee
blog.title: My Distractions
blog.description: 30-something spinster fangirl. I blog about: MCU & occasionally other fandoms, ace/aro stuff, spooky things.

summary: An actual argument I have seen online re: time in Endgame: Time is linear (so a time loop can form) as long as they (time...
body:
An actual argument I have seen online re: time in Endgame:

Time is linear (so a time loop can form) as long as they (time travelers) don’t change certain things. In the scene with the ancient one there was only a split if the stones stayed gone, but they were returned so it’s all the same timeline. When the stones aren’t in the correct place at the correct time it’s a multiverse situation, so that explains how Nebula shot her past self, because that timeline, without the stone, was ‘doomed.’

To quote Lewis Black: “I don’t have enough breadcrumbs to get home.”

For one, what are ‘certain things’? Just removing the stones? But Loki took the Tesseract, so even if they return the stones they took, Loki still took the stone in 2012, so what happens with that? Is time not linear in that one instance? Also, if they didn’t have to worry about messing up the past beyond removing the stones because things would just be reset somehow (which is not explained in the movie - what is explained is that the stones get returned and the timeline isn’t doomed; not that it is magically reset), why did they even bother dressing up as their past selves and trying to steal them totally unnoticed? And once they return the stones to the timeline (or reality, still not clear if these are interchangeable) does 2014 Nebula just pop back into existence? This isn’t explained either.)

And we aren’t just going by what the Ancient One said, but what Bruce explained, too, about not being able to affect your own past. If you can’t affect your own past, the time loop is not a thing. And he wasn’t talking about taking the stones out at all. The Ancient One didn’t directly contradict anything that Bruce said, just added to it.

I just… the more I see people attempt to explain Endgame’s logic like the rest of us just didn’t get it, the more ticked off I get because, no, I got it fine. The writers and directors didn’t put enough thought into it to make it make sense, simple as that (and that’s still not even close to my biggest, character-assassinating problem with Endgame, but it’s still super irritating to see all the defenses of something so nonsensical and poorly-explained).

reblog.comment:
An actual argument I have seen online re: time in Endgame:

Time is linear (so a time loop can form) as long as they (time travelers) don’t change certain things. In the scene with the ancient one there was only a split if the stones stayed gone, but they were returned so it’s all the same timeline. When the stones aren’t in the correct place at the correct time it’s a multiverse situation, so that explains how Nebula shot her past self, because that timeline, without the stone, was ‘doomed.’

To quote Lewis Black: “I don’t have enough breadcrumbs to get home.”

For one, what are ‘certain things’? Just removing the stones? But Loki took the Tesseract, so even if they return the stones they took, Loki still took the stone in 2012, so what happens with that? Is time not linear in that one instance? Also, if they didn’t have to worry about messing up the past beyond removing the stones because things would just be reset somehow (which is not explained in the movie - what is explained is that the stones get returned and the timeline isn’t doomed; not that it is magically reset), why did they even bother dressing up as their past selves and trying to steal them totally unnoticed? And once they return the stones to the timeline (or reality, still not clear if these are interchangeable) does 2014 Nebula just pop back into existence? This isn’t explained either.)

And we aren’t just going by what the Ancient One said, but what Bruce explained, too, about not being able to affect your own past. If you can’t affect your own past, the time loop is not a thing. And he wasn’t talking about taking the stones out at all. The Ancient One didn’t directly contradict anything that Bruce said, just added to it.

I just… the more I see people attempt to explain Endgame’s logic like the rest of us just didn’t get it, the more ticked off I get because, no, I got it fine. The writers and directors didn’t put enough thought into it to make it make sense, simple as that (and that’s still not even close to my biggest, character-assassinating problem with Endgame, but it’s still super irritating to see all the defenses of something so nonsensical and poorly-explained).

summary: i need a video of the marvel women to the song feel invincible by skillet. because that’s the song that gets stuck in my head...
body:
i need a video of the marvel women to the song feel invincible by skillet. because that’s the song that gets stuck in my head whenever i see all these badass women come together in that one scene in endgame.

you make me feel invincible
earthquake, powerful
just like a tidal wave
you make me brave

yes. yes, they do. damn, do i feel good whenever i see that scene. and fuck everyone who says it’s shit!
